lead_paragraph: Think tanks are seen as independent, but their scholars often push donors’ agendas, amplifying a culture of corporate influence in Washington.

byline.contributor: Brooke Williams is a reporter at the New England Center for Investigative Reporting, which collaborated with The New York Times on this series. Audrey Stuart contributed reporting from Cannes, France. Kitty Bennett contributed research.
byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON and BROOKE WILLIAMS

headline.print_headline: Scholarship or Business? Think Tanks Blur the Line
headline.main: How Think Tanks Amplify Corporate America’s Influence

snippet: Think tanks are seen as independent, but their scholars often push donors’ agendas, amplifying a culture of corporate influence in Washington....
abstract: Analysis of thousands of pages of internal and sometimes confidential documentation sheds light on true political power of think tanks, long seen as independent of moneyed interests; in chase for  funds, such research organizations are pushing agendas important to corporate donors, sometimes blurring line between researchers and lobbyists, while reaping benefits of tax-exempt status (Series: Think Tanks Inc).

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Center for Strategic and International Studies
